Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT13-COX 
    

 UPDATE      UPDATE
      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR THURSDAY, July 13, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   Eds. Adds: MIDEAST-SUMMIT, SUMMIT-PERSONA, US-TRADE,
NIRELAND-MARCHES, DECKS, BBN-REDS, BBN-BRAVES-TRADE, BIG-RIGS,
FLOORING, AIR-ADS, DELTA-BLACKS, EMU, DAVIDIAN , PARENTHOOD

   Deletes: HEAT, EDITORIAL-LEE

   INTERNATIONAL

   FRANCE-CHALLENGES _ France has just taken over the rotating
presidency of the European Union and is riding a winning streak at
home: Consumer confidence is high. The World Health Organization
just rated France the nation with the best healthcare. And the
French even won the European soccer championship this month, making
their team the first to ever hold the world and Europe
championships at the same time. But, as Bastille Day approaches,
the nation also faces new challenges _ some of them prickly ones
related to the EU leadership. A talk with Consul General Jean-Paul
Monchau. (Graham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   MIDEAST-SUMMIT _THURMONT, Md. _ Spot coverage of the final
status peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians. The talks _
operating under a news blackout _ will focus on three issues: the
future of Jerusalem; borders of a Palestinian state; and fate of
millions of Palestinian refugees around the world. Developing.
(Deans, Cox News Service).

   WITH

   SUMMIT-PERSONAL _ THURMONT, Md. _ A close, colorful and
anecdotal look at the personal diplomacy that goes into making a
summit like this successful. As President Carter at Camp David I,
personalities can make all the difference. Developing. (Deans, Cox
News Service).

   NIRELAND-MARCHES _ BELFAST, Northern Ireland _ Spot coverage of
the Glorious 12th and the climax of the Protestant marching season.
Developing. (Roughton, Cox News Service).

   US-TRADE _ WASHINGTON _ The Senate Foreign Relations Committee's
International economic policy, export and trade promotion
subcommittee holds a hearing on potential uses of biotechnology to
alleviate poverty and hunger in developing countries _ focusing on
sub-Saharan Africa. Andrew Young, chairman of GoodWorks
International, testifies. (Michals, Cox News Service).

   Expected to move on the NYT Wire in both International and
Washington categories.

   NATIONAL

   NAACP-GORE _ BALTIMORE - Saying ``talk is cheap,'' Vice
President Al Gore launched a stinging attack Wednesday at the NAACP
convention on George W. Bush, his presidential rival. Gore said
Bush's words of conciliation to the convention this week mean
little next to years of Republican inaction or hostility on issues
important to blacks. (Shepard, Cox News Service).

   BUSH - Bush speaks to top Republicans from around the country
just weeks before he formally claims his party's nomination for
president. (Herman, Austin American-Statesman)

   UNDOING-RACISM _ NEW ORLEANS, La. - The People's Institute for
Survival and Beyond, founded by the Rev. C.T. Vivian in Atlanta, is
celebrating its 20th anniversary with the announcement today of the
opening of a training school here. The institute, which holds
Undoing Racism workshops among others, will draw community
organizers from throughout the United States for workshops and
strategy sessions. It will be the first training school in the deep
South and will be located on Oretha Castle Haley Boulevard, where
it is hoped the school will play a role in furthering redevelopment
of the historic African-American district. (Manuel, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 28.

   CAPITOL-SLAVES _ WASHINGTON _ Reps. John Lewis, D-Ga., and J.C.
Watts, R-Okla., hold a news conference to discuss their call for a
special House task force to study the contributions of slaves in
building the U.S. Capitol. (Garcia, Cox News Service)

   DAVIDIAN _ Coverage of Davidian civil trial. (England, Wac
Tribune-Herald) WITH PHOTO.EMU _ ATLANTA _ Found: One emu. A little
tattered after long walk from somewhere, since emus don't fly.
Likes dog food. Needs good home, preferably with other emus to play
with. After a stray emu showed up on his doorstep last week, a
Conyers man took the hapless, 4-foot bird into his home _ back
yard, rather _ and has been looking for its rightful owners. But
animal control officials say when the bottom dropped out of the emu
breeding market recently, financially strapped bird ranchers
started turning the animals out like stray cats. (Jones, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOHEALTH-SAFETY _ WASHINGTON _ A
Senate subcommittee Thursday focuses on proposed federal safety
standards for hospitals and nursing homes that conservatives say
would cost too much. Much of the health care industry resists the
standards, despite success stories like on Seattle hospital that
reduced staff injuries by two-thirds and days lost to injury by by
80 percent in a test of a specialized patient lifting team.
(Malone, Cox News Service)

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) MOVED.

   PARENTHOOD _ WASHINGTON _ Planned Parenthood, eager to subvert
Gov. George W. Bush's compassionate conservative mantra, is
launching a $2.5 million advertising campaign aimed at Republican
and independent women who support abortion rights and at swing
voters in key Midwestern states. (Austin American-Statesman)

   UNLICENSED _ WASHINGTON _ One out of every five fatal car
crashes involves a driver with an invalid license, according to a
study issued Wednesday by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety.
(O'Dell, Cox News Service)

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   JOEMURRAY-COLUMN _ LUFKIN, Texas _ I stopped by my doctor's
office this week for help with an insurance form, still trying to
get reimbursed for a medical bill I paid last December. That was
back when I last had pneumonia. The doctor cured me, but it looks
like I'm going to die of frustration waiting for the insurance
company to pay me what it owes me. (Murray, Lufkin Daily News)
MOVED

   MCCARTY-COLUMN _ DAYTON, Ohio _ This is not a time for
pettiness, but I can't help feeling peeved that, until last fall, I
appear to have been the only person in town who didn't know Joe
Belle. (McCarty, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.

   NETHAWAY-COLUMN _ At the same time that Congress is arguing over
providing health care for elderly Americans, old folks are
complaining that they are not old. A peppery friend of my mother
gets upset when the ``press,'' which is me, refers to someone her
age as elderly, old or senior. (Nethaway, Waco Tribune-Herald).
MOVED.

   KELSO-COLUMN _ We're going to try to set the world record right
here in Austin for packing the most number of guys named Herb into
an herb bar. (Kelso, Austin American-Statesman). MOVED.

   BUSINESS

   MINORITIES _ A federal commission releases a study Thursday
saying that nowhere near enough minorities and women are going into
the fields of science, engineering and technology to fuel the needs
for the future. A black Georgia Tech professor is involved in the
study and has been waging a one-man battle here to increase numbers
of African Americans entering these fields. (Holsendolph, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   AIRTRAN _ AirTran releases 2Q earnings. Word is they'll have a
nice profit as intense demand offsets higher fuel costs. (Thurston,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   DELTA-BLACKS _Delta Air Lines is underwriting a summer aviation
camp for black students run by the Organization of Black Airline
Pilots. (Thurston, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   AIR-ADS _ Airline passengers will be reading ads as they look
for space in overhead bins if a Missouri company has its way.
Advent Inc. wants to sell advertising placards that would be stuck
on ov

   FLOORING _ Flooring America, which recently filed for bankruptcy
protection, has lost four of its top officers, including the new
chairman and CEO, David Nichols. The top level shake-up adds to the
company's troubles: FA restated fiscal 1999 earnings downward; has
closed stores and laid-off workers. But Nichols was supposed to
turn it around. (Bond, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   LIFESTYLE

   BRAIN _ AUSTIN, Texas _ UT researchers and some colleagues from
Stanford believe they have made some advancements in brain
research, using MRIs so finely tuned that they can watch oxygen
cells travel within the brain. This, in turn, allows the scientists
to see how specific regions of the brain control specific actions.
And it may ultimately allow doctors to do a better job of treating
brain disorders. (Roser, Austin American-Statesman)

   NEWS-QUESTIONS _ Q&A on the news, in two takes. (Bessonette,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   EDs: Moving in l (Lifestyle) and a (General News) categories.)

   HOME&GARDEN

   GARDENING-LIFE _ Gardeners always have known that talking about
plants, sharing experiences, is a large part of what makes digging
in the dirt such a powerful connection.(May, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution.)

   APARTMENT-REDO _ Adding pizazz to your apartment doesn't have to
swallow your savings. Two local interior designers take a basic
one-bedroom apartment at Post Stratford Apts. in Buckhead and give
it new life - for less than $500 per room. We show you how and
offer some general tips on decorating small spaces. (AHill, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   PLANTWORKS _ This week's Plant Works feature by Diana Blowers.
This one focuses on zinnias. (Dayton Daily News)

   TV-EXPERT _ Katie Brown, a lifestyle expert and host of Lifetime
TV's ``Next Door with Katie Brown,'' knows how to decorate a home
on the cheap. For her, it's all about color. Brown shares painting
tips and gives decorating advice. (AHill, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   DECKS - Consider other materials in addition to pressure-treated
lumber when constructing a deck. (Dayton Daily News) MOVED.

   CONSUMER NEWS

   BUYER'S-EDGE _ July is National Ice Cream Month _ a great time
to throw an ice cream social. We show you some fun ways to serve
the frozen treats and some super scoopers. (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). WITH PHOTOS and LAYOUT.

   SHOPPING-GUIDE _ A weekly feature telling how to locate
hard-to-fnd items. This week: (Johnson, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). WITH PHOTOS and LAYOUT.

   SHOPPING-DESTINATION _ A weekly feature about fun places to shop
in the Southeast. This week: (Atlanta Journal-Constitution). WITH
PHOTOS and LAYOUT.

   FOOD

   COXNET FOOD PAGE

   EDs: This is the CoxNet FOOD page for the current week. This
layout is available now.

   COXNET FOOD 0708: AMERICAN PIE _ Whether based on fruits, nuts,
vegetables or custards, pies have played a rich role in our
culinary heritage for hundreds of years. (Norris, Palm Beach Post)
Art includes a 5-column color photo illustration of an Apple Pie
with American icons, a 18-pica color photo of a apple pie and a
2-column color photo of a maple nutcracker pie.

   WITH

   TIPS BOX _ Tips for making a perfect crust. Art includes a
1-column color photo of three cherries.

   BAKING TIPS _ Tips on how to make perfect pies.

   RECIPE _ Recipe for Cherry Pie.

   CYBERSPICE _ Many cooks choose to improve their dishes by adding
liquor. (Parham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   (END OF COXNET FOOD PAGE)

   FOOD-BRUSCHETTA _ Bruschetta and crostini, Italy's answer to
garlic bread, has been the darling of American restaurants and
trendy cocktail parties for a couple of decades. But in Italy,
they've been essential to everyday life for centuries. Once you've
tasted the real thing, it's no wonder they've lasted so long. And
because they are versatile and quick especially adaptable to both
modern entertaining and hectic weeknight meals. (Puckett, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH COLOR PHOTO and LAYOUT.

   FOOD-BRUSCHETTA-RECIPES _ Recipe page to go with BRUSCHETTA
story centerpieced on AJC weekly food section. (Puckett, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH LAYOUT.

   FOOD-RECIPESWAP _A weekly recipe exchange column. This week:
Charlie Trotter's Cobb Salad (Langhenry, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FOOD-CYBERSPICE _ A weekly column looking at the plethora of
recipes on the Internet. (Parham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   FOOD-EGGS _ Are pasteurized eggs all they are cracked up to be?
We put them to the test in several recipes and found they look a
little funny (cloudy whites) and taste a little bland, and whites
take much longer to beat into stiff peaks. But the eggs are a
welcome addition to the grocery shelf, especially for recipes
calling for raw eggs, like homemade mayo. (Walker, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   ENTERTAINMENT-ARTS

   KASELL _ WASHINGTON _ Interview and profile of Carl Kasell, the
veteran newsman of National Public Radio. (Dart, Cox News Service).
30. WITH PHOTO.

   EDs: Moving on the NYT wire in (w) Washington and (e)
entertainment categories.

   GOSPEL _ Stirring spiritual music doesn't just roll in off the
street. It has to be carried in on the voices of talented artists
who have the ability to anoint as well as entertain. The Miami
Valley is blessed with a rich vein of gospel performers who,
regrettably, don't get the exposure they deserve. Thankfully, a
handful of these performers _ along with a splash of national and
regional artists _ will have the chance to showcase their talents
this weekend at three gospel extravaganzas. (Dayton Daily News)
WITH PHOTOS MOVED.

   XMEN _ It started in 1963 as The Uncanny X-Men. The comic book
by Stan Lee introduced five pupils at Xavier's School for Gifted
Youngsters. They possessed a mutant ``X gene'' that gives them
special powers that humans fear and distrust. Professor Charles
Xavier teaches these five X-Men to control their emerging powers to
fight evil and help mutants and humans coexist. While the comic
book has been a top seller for decades and spawned a popular Fox
cartoon, not many people know just who the X-Men are. That may
change with Friday's big-screen movie X-Men, starring Patrick
Stewart, Ian McKellen and Halle Berry, and directed by Bryan Singer
(''The Usual Suspects''). So, you're not a cult comic book reader.
Here's a guide to the characters and story of the superhero tales.
(Thomas, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   VIDEO-HURRICANE _ Video of the week: ``The Hurricane.'' Grade:
B. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   VIDEO-MINIS _ Coming soon: ``Angela's Ashes,'' ``The Ninth
Gate,'' ``Ride With the Devil,'' ``Diamonds,'' ``Rosetta,'' ``The
Whole Nine Yards,'' ``The Big Tease,'' ``The War Zone,'' ``Isn't
She Great,'' ``What Planet Are You From?'' (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   VIDEO-SPOTLIGHT _ Does ``EdTV'' and ``The Truman Show'' seem so
far-fetched now? With ``Survivor'' and ``Big Brother'' overtaking
the tube, we look at films that explore ways in which television
consumes our lives _ from ``Being There'' and ``Network'' to
``Pleasantville'' and ``My Favorite Year.'' (Longino, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   VIDEO-RINGEL _ (Ringel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   AUDIO-NUTTY _ Sonia Murray reviews ``The Nutty Professor''
soundtrack. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   AUDIO-MINIS _ Mini reviews of Kansas, Ruff Ryder, others TBA.
(Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   AUDIO-COUNTRY/RAP/POP _ (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WRESTLING-GRAPEVINE _ Our wrestling columnist keeps up with the
latest twists and turns of the soap opera of professional wrestling
_ in the ring and behind the scenes. (Allen, Cox News Service)
MOVED.

   SPORTS

   ALL-STAR GAME REVIEW

   BBO-ALL-STAR-COX _ Derek Jeter leads American League to another
victory. (Stinson, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   BB0-ALL-STAR-HUMMER _ ATLANTA _ No more regrets over what this
All-Star Game wasn't. That kind of thinking can be so wasteful
anyway, as almost any cancer patient will tell you. The complaints
over all the players who no-showed Tuesday night were to be washed
away in steady waves of appreciation for one player you couldn't
have kept away with a sore knee or a restraining order. (Hummer,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   BBO-ALL-STAR-MVP _ Derek Jeter first Yankee to earn MVP honors.
(Wilkinson, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   OTHER BASEBALL ITEMS

   BBN-BRAVES _ The Atlanta Braves enter second half of 2000 season
with a lot of questions.... and very few answers. (Rogers, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   BBN-REDS _ The Reds traded Denny Neagle, their top starting
pitcher, to the New York Yankees for the rights to four minor
league players. (Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   BBN-MCCOY-COLUMN _ Now that the Reds have traded their best
pitcher, does that mean they are waving the white flag on this
season? What's ahead for the Reds who say thir goal is to bring
championship baseball to Cincy by 2003. (McCoy, Dayton Daily News)

   BBN-BRAVES-TRADE _Braves trade to get pitcher Andy Ashby.
(Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   FOOTBALL

   COLLEGES

   FBC-BOWDEN _ Another ugly legal battle is brewing between Terry
Bowden and Auburn, which wants the former coach to either pay up or
move out of his palatial home on The Plains. (Barnhart, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   PROS

   FBN-FALCONS _ The Falcons attended the voluntary passing camp
last month in huge numbers and everyone eagerly attended mini-camp.
Now the players are all expected to arrive in Greenville, S.C.
today without any problems for the beginning of training camp.
(Winkeljohn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BASKETBALL

   BKN-DEMARR _ Instead of preparing for his sophomore season at
the University of Cincinnati, DerMarr Johnson is preparing for life
in the NBA as a lottery pick with the Atlanta Hawks. The Hawks are
counting on Johnson to make a huge impact on the team next season,
but is Johnson ready for the challenge? We will take a look at the
team's top draft pick as he completes his first week as a pro.
(Hayes, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BKN-HEAT _ Heat pursuing McGrady. (Skolnick, Palm Beach Post)

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EST and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   The day news editor is Tom Oder, 404-526-5887,
toder(at)coxnews.com.

   The night news editor is Todd C. Duncan, 404-582-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com.

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
Text:
For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

NIRELAND-MARCHES, DECKS, BBN-REDS, BBN-BRAVES-TRADE, BIG-RIGS,
FLOORING, AIR-ADS, DELTA-BLACKS, EMU, DAVIDIAN , PARENTHOOD

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) MOVED.

Advent Inc. wants to sell advertising placards that would be stuck
on ov

company's troubles: FA restated fiscal 1999 earnings downward; has

   LIFESTYLE

   BRAIN _ AUSTIN, Texas _ UT researchers and some colleagues from

Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   EDs: Moving in l (Lifestyle) and a (General News) categories.)

   HOME&GARDEN

   GARDENING-LIFE _ Gardeners always have known that talking about
plants, sharing experiences, is a large part of what makes digging

Journal-Constitution.)

   APARTMENT-REDO _ Adding pizazz to your apartment doesn't have to

Journal-Constitution)

This one focuses on zinnias. (Dayton Daily News)

Journal-Constitution)

lumber when constructing a deck. (Dayton Daily News) MOVED.

   CONSUMER NEWS

   COXNET FOOD PAGE

layout is available now.

   COXNET FOOD 0708: AMERICAN PIE _ Whether based on fruits, nuts,
vegetables or custards, pies have played a rich role in our
culinary heritage for hundreds of years. (Norris, Palm Beach Post)
Art includes a 5-column color photo illustration of an Apple Pie
with American icons, a 18-pica color photo of a apple pie and a
2-column color photo of a maple nutcracker pie.

   WITH

   TIPS BOX _ Tips for making a perfect crust. Art includes a
1-column color photo of three cherries.

   BAKING TIPS _ Tips on how to make perfect pies.

   RECIPE _ Recipe for Cherry Pie.

   CYBERSPICE _ Many cooks choose to improve their dishes by adding
liquor. (Parham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   (END OF COXNET FOOD PAGE)

   FOOD-BRUSCHETTA _ Bruschetta and crostini, Italy's answer to
garlic bread, has been the darling of American restaurants and
trendy cocktail parties for a couple of decades. But in Italy,
they've been essential to everyday life for centuries. Once you've
tasted the real thing, it's no wonder they've lasted so long. And
because they are versatile and quick especially adaptable to both
modern entertaining and hectic weeknight meals. (Puckett, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH COLOR PHOTO and LAYOUT.

   FOOD-BRUSCHETTA-RECIPES _ Recipe page to go with BRUSCHETTA
story centerpieced on AJC weekly food section. (Puckett, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH LAYOUT.

   FOOD-RECIPESWAP _A weekly recipe exchange column. This week:
Charlie Trotter's Cobb Salad (Langhenry, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FOOD-CYBERSPICE _ A weekly column looking at the plethora of
recipes on the Internet. (Parham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   FOOD-EGGS _ Are pasteurized eggs all they are cracked up to be?
We put them to the test in several recipes and found they look a
little funny (cloudy whites) and taste a little bland, and whites
take much longer to beat into stiff peaks. But the eggs are a
welcome addition to the grocery shelf, especially for recipes
calling for raw eggs, like homemade mayo. (Walker, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   ENTERTAINMENT-ARTS

   KASELL _ WASHINGTON _ Interview and profile of Carl Kasell, the
veteran newsman of National Public Radio. (Dart, Cox News Service).
30. WITH PHOTO.

   EDs: Moving on the NYT wire in (w) Washington and (e)
entertainment categories.

   GOSPEL _ Stirring spiritual music doesn't just roll in off the
street. It has to be carried in on the voices of talented artists
who have the ability to anoint as well as entertain. The Miami
Valley is blessed with a rich vein of gospel performers who,
regrettably, don't get the exposure they deserve. Thankfully, a
handful of these performers _ along with a splash of national and
regional artists _ will have the chance to showcase their talents
this weekend at three gospel extravaganzas. (Dayton Daily News)
WITH PHOTOS MOVED.

   XMEN _ It started in 1963 as The Uncanny X-Men. The comic book
by Stan Lee introduced five pupils at Xavier's School for Gifted
Youngsters. They possessed a mutant ``X gene'' that gives them
special powers that humans fear and distrust. Professor Charles
Xavier teaches these five X-Men to control their emerging powers to
fight evil and help mutants and humans coexist. While the comic
book has been a top seller for decades and spawned a popular Fox
cartoon, not many people know just who the X-Men are. That may
change with Friday's big-screen movie X-Men, starring Patrick
Stewart, Ian McKellen and Halle Berry, and directed by Bryan Singer
(''The Usual Suspects''). So, you're not a cult comic book reader.
Here's a guide to the characters and story of the superhero tales.
(Thomas, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   VIDEO-HURRICANE _ Video of the week: ``The Hurricane.'' Grade:
B. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   VIDEO-MINIS _ Coming soon: ``Angela's Ashes,'' ``The Ninth
Gate,'' ``Ride With the Devil,'' ``Diamonds,'' ``Rosetta,'' ``The
Whole Nine Yards,'' ``The Big Tease,'' ``The War Zone,'' ``Isn't
She Great,'' ``What Planet Are You From?'' (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   VIDEO-SPOTLIGHT _ Does ``EdTV'' and ``The Truman Show'' seem so
far-fetched now? With ``Survivor'' and ``Big Brother'' overtaking
the tube, we look at films that explore ways in which television
consumes our lives _ from ``Being There'' and ``Network'' to
``Pleasantville'' and ``My Favorite Year.'' (Longino, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   SPORTS

   ALL-STAR GAME REVIEW

   BBO-ALL-STAR-COX _ Derek Jeter leads American League to another
victory. (Stinson, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   BB0-ALL-STAR-HUMMER _ ATLANTA _ No more regrets over what this
All-Star Game wasn't. That kind of thinking can be so wasteful
anyway, as almost any cancer patient will tell you. The complaints
over all the players who no-showed Tuesday night were to be washed
away in steady waves of appreciation for one player you couldn't
have kept away with a sore knee or a restraining order. (Hummer,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   BBO-ALL-STAR-MVP _ Derek Jeter first Yankee to earn MVP honors.
(Wilkinson, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   OTHER BASEBALL ITEMS

   BBN-BRAVES _ The Atlanta Braves enter second half of 2000 season
with a lot of questions.... and very few answers. (Rogers, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   BBN-REDS _ The Reds traded Denny Neagle, their top starting
pitcher, to the New York Yankees for the rights to four minor
league players. (Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   BBN-MCCOY-COLUMN _ Now that the Reds have traded their best
pitcher, does that mean they are waving the white flag on this
season? What's ahead for the Reds who say thir goal is to bring
championship baseball to Cincy by 2003. (McCoy, Dayton Daily News)

   BBN-BRAVES-TRADE _Braves trade to get pitcher Andy Ashby.
(Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   FOOTBALL

   COLLEGES

   FBC-BOWDEN _ Another ugly legal battle is brewing between Terry
Bowden and Auburn, which wants the former coach to either pay up or
move out of his palatial home on The Plains. (Barnhart, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   PROS

   FBN-FALCONS _ The Falcons attended the voluntary passing camp
last month in huge numbers and everyone eagerly attended mini-camp.
Now the players are all expected to arrive in Greenville, S.C.
today without any problems for the beginning of training camp.
(Winkeljohn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BASKETBALL

   BKN-DEMARR _ Instead of preparing for his sophomore season at
the University of Cincinnati, DerMarr Johnson is preparing for life
in the NBA as a lottery pick with the Atlanta Hawks. The Hawks are
counting on Johnson to make a huge impact on the team next season,
but is Johnson ready for the challenge? We will take a look at the
team's top draft pick as he completes his first week as a pro.
(Hayes, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BKN-HEAT _ Heat pursuing McGrady. (Skolnick, Palm Beach Post)
